captions.text: Do humans ENJOY being free?

Existentialist Jean Paul Sartre
claimed that because there is no God, we are
CONDEMNED to be free.

In his essay “Existentialism is a
Humanism”, Sartre famously said that “Existence

precedes Essence.” In other words, one first
exists,
and THEN one invents one’s “self”
through the choices he makes.

But such freedom can be quite
daunting, and leads to feelings of abandonment,

despair and forlorness. For not only is there
no God to guide us, but our total freedom

means each one of us is solely responsible
for what he becomes. Sartre says that to alleviate

this burden of choice, we will attempt to
deceive ourselves by acting as if we are not
free, or what he calls “acting in bad faith.”

Consider a situation in which a
woman contemplates leaving her husband for

her lover. Is she prepared to face the consequences
of such a critical choice- a choice that only
SHE can make?

Instead of choosing, she may lure
them to a meeting where she will idly allow
them to fight over her.

The hope is one will prevail,
sparing her of the responsibility of choosing

herself. By relinquishing her choice, she
leaves it up to somebody else to define who
she is, and thus, she acts in Bad Faith.

In fact, every second of the day we
make choices that define us. The self is constantly
changing, always an “open question.”

For example, one may perform a
certain job, such as a knight, but one is
never identical to one’s role.

Imagine a man named Nigel has the job of being
a mage. A mage's role is easily defined-

one casts
black magic to vanquish their enemies. But

when he does this, is he making the choice
as Nigel, or as a mage?

If he chooses to merely equate
himself with his role of “mage”- he

will execute his actions in a mechanical,
overzealous way. He doesn’t actually choose

his actions as his own, rather he merely acts
in accordance with how people expect a mage
to act. Thus, he is in bad faith.

But is choosing not to choose not
also a choice?

However we may try to delude
ourselves, there is no escaping our freedom.

title: Do We Enjoy Being Free? (Final Fantasy + Sartre) - 8-Bit Philosophy

comments.text:
I'll tell this to the people who tell me I don't have a right to an opinion 
because I don't vote.﻿
comments.author: Nathan Sharp

comments.text:
Freedom is a bit of an illusion I think. If being free means that we can 
make choices independent of other factors, only based on our will. Aren't 
our wills completely determined by other factors beyond us? Not god 
necessarily, but our genes, memories, cognitive structures, and sensory 
perception. Aren't all of those created or set into motion long before our 
lives even begin by events we did not inform? What else makes up our 
decision-making process but those things?﻿
comments.author: CycleInterruption

comments.text:
Heidegger misinterpreted by a profound genius. Being and Nothingness is one 
easy lesson.﻿
comments.author: Timothy Smith

comments.text:
I consider the idea that we're free to be very incorrect. We're ruled by 
our impulses and animalistic instincts. Furthermore, we're unconsciously 
conditioned by media, peer groups and more. In reality, these ideas fall 
apart. If you're born in the middle-east, chances are you'll be Muslim. In 
Russia, you'd be orthodox Christian, and so on. In my opinion, we have to 
stop this arrogance about humans being the center of the universe and 
everything revolves around us, that we're free to do as we please, and 
after admitting that, we can become self aware to our habits and then, like 
science, take bias out of knowledge. Do things for good reasons, not merely 
"everyone else is doing it"...﻿

comments.text:
This is nonsensical... Any choice you make could be interpreted as 
'bad-faith' as every choice made is in some form or fashion influenced, 
right down to the synaptic level. The ancient form of thought that alluded 
to passions rather than emotions makes more sense biologically. Sartre 
seems to want to suggest that there is thought somehow independent of the 
brain, but without the products of the brain one has no way of 'thinking' 
and thus is subject to such a capacity. Whether or not the mind is subject 
to all physical mechanics in the most minute sense is a mystery, but the 
mind will always and has always been subject to those base physiological 
mechanics which are recognized by chemistry.

ie we are always the mage acting like the mage.﻿

comments.author: Brian Edwards

comments.text:
Yeah I don't think Sartre's bad faith = determinism.  I think he's assuming 
that there are real choices.  I mean, one can argue that choices don't 
really alter reality, but can you really deny that choices don't even 
exist?  Subjectively - there seems to be some control over a situation, the 
ability to choose among alternatives.  Bad faith then is when you make a 
choice, but sort of disown it at the same time.  You're alluding to some 
model for your decision making in this case.  I really wonder why we do 
this anyways.  Perhaps maintaining an idealized form of self. And/or 
escaping responsibility.  It's sad really.

comments.text:
If existence precedes essence then essences are not real. Ergo, concepts - 
which are essences existing in the mind - are not real. Ergo "Sartre" does 
not exist to even make his own argument. What fun to play this game! 
Sartre's philosophy of freedom only makes sense if "man" as such exists. 
That is, he implicitly assumes there are such things as real "humans", but 
denies the basis for which such an assumption can be made (i.e. the 
existences of essences.)﻿

determinism notwithstanding). You can still decide against the will of the

can do most of those same things, and we don't consider that a rejoinder to 
existential freedom. (Again, taking physical determinism, which I 
personally find credible, out of consideration for the sake of the 
argument.)﻿

comments.text:
I enjoy being free.
If I didn't, then I wouldn't be who I am, would I?

If I did everything society expected me to do, I'd be the biggest douche 
you'd ever met.
(Though, a lot of you are pretty shitty.)
If I did everything everyone else expected me to do, I'd be some soulless 
religious scholarly prick.
(We already have so many of them.)

I've always known for so long the kind of person I wanted to be.
I found that person, while looking deep into the shadow of my own twisted 
mind.
I'm not that person, but I'm not what other people want me to be.
I'm not what anyone wants me to be.

I'm just... me.﻿

comments.text:
Am I suspecting correctly that Satre (as he is portrayed here) means 
something different with "freedom" than Kant in Ep. 3? That he would have a 
point even when humans would operate like computers?

If we consider the woman in the story: I think she isn't free. Her decision 
to lure the men into a fight is determined by some facts: She is not 
mentally strong enough to dismiss one, She doesn't have a strong preference 
for either man. (You could argue her neurons were determined to fire a 
certain pattern.)

What I agree on, is that one shouldn't be afraid to make choices. Would 
Satre say that a soldier is to be held responsible for things he does by 
command?﻿

comments.author: Dartinin

comments.text:
+Dartinin You don't have proof that you exist. "I think, therefore I am" is 
not even an argument as it is missing a premise. The only thing that 
follows from the premise, I think is that I think, which is merely a 
tautology. If you want to warrant the conclusion that I exist then you need 
more premises. However, Søren Kierkegaard pointed out that once we 
disambiguate the terms and add the missing premises we can see that the 
cogito begs the question. Observe:

"x" thinks

I am that "x"

Therefore I think

Therefore I am

the proper logical flow of argument is that existence is already assumed or 
presupposed in order for thinking to occur, not that existence is concluded 
from that thinking. It already assumes there really is an "I" in the first 
premise. So Descartes ends up begging the question in order to prove his 
own existence, and thus this is not proof of his own existence, and nor is 
this proof of your existence.
comments.author: Gaining Understanding

comments.text:
"solely responsible for what he becomes" What a joke. That is not at all 
true. If you are born into a Christan family you will become christian. If 
you are abused growing up, you will develop emotional problems, etc etc. 
The environment you live in is what decides what you become, not the other 
way around.


To those who are saying I am wrong, You do not know what the fuck you are 
talking about.

While yes, you can make your own choices and can choice to follow whatever 
religion but you can not say that the religion you grow up around does not 
influence you, or that the people who you grow up around does not influence 
you and your world views. While yes, you can make the final choice to 
believe in god, to be racist or not, to like movies or books, what have you 
but your environment plays HEAVILY on those choices.

So yes, The environment plays a HUGE part in who you become as a human 
being.﻿

comments.author: lordblazer

comments.text:
I grew up in a Christian home, I was abused, and I never had anyone to 
teach me.

I don't believe in "God", or at least how Christians believe 
him/her/it/whatever to be.
I was abused as a child, and from that, I learned how to be kind. I won't 
take shit from everybody, but that's something I decided later on in my 
life.
By the time I was seven, I had decided who, and what I wanted to be.

Nobody told me about the world, or what it expected of me.
I knew where I wanted to be, what role I wanted to play, and how I would 
live my life.
By that time, I was more mature than most people my age. Hell, I was more 
mature than most adults are today.

I know a lot of people who grew up with the same circumstances I did,
Sure, there are similarities in how they developed, but the end results can 
be unique, and unusual.

I'm smart, but I'm also pretty dumb.
I'm insane, but in a way that not even most psychiatrists can understand.
I have problems, but they're the type of problems you can't see from any 
point but mine.

Let me ask you a question, to anyone who might read this.
If you only had one chance, to gain everything you ever wanted, would you 
take it, or just let it slip?
comments.author: Fernando Cruz

comments.text: is choosing how to react to your environment not a choice that you make?
comments.author: derp derpington

comments.text:
+TheBlarggle
 But if you grow up in a poor family who does not even have a toilet or a 
sink, you would have to go down to the lake and get piss poor infected 
water which you would have to boil. Choices can be very limited, and some 
people have much better choices then others. The environment you grow up in 
chooses the choices you are given.
comments.author: Conan

comments.text:
+TheBlarggle
 Those are hardly choices, They are "choices" forced apon you. Your choices 
can be extrmeley limited and forced apon you depending where you grow up, 
who your family was, who your friends are, and many more factors. Choice is 
a illusion.
comments.author: Conan

comments.text:
+Conan Choice is still choice, and you have it whether limited or not. 
You're being raped? Fine you're put in a situation you didn't control, but 
you still have choices. Do you fight back and hope to get away? Do you 
fight back and get killed in the process? Do you let it happen and hope 
that you live through the process? Those are all choices to make. It's a 
horrible situation to be sure. You never chose to be raped, but you've got 
choices to make concerning yourself. And the choices of the the offender 
matter as well. They chose to rape someone. 

In the matter of slavery, you still have choices... You can choose not to 
eat, and starve yourself to death. You can choose to try and escape. You 
can choose to fight back.

No one ever said you have "Good and Bad" choices. Some people only have 
"Bad and Worse" choices to make. The slave has only bad choices to make. 
The rape-victim has only bad choices to make. The choices made may have 
good or bad outcomes, but choosing to fight, run, or die are still choices. 
They just might not be good choices. And you become what follows from those 
choices. A survivor, a free man, or a corpse to name a few. 

Emotionally you can succumb and become what your environment has 
predisposed for you, or you can **TRY** to make something different happen. 
Either way, you're still choosing. And as said in the video, for even 
choosing **NOT** to choose is still a choice.
comments.author: TheBlarggle

comments.text:
I have found that we still make choices to agree to what our environment 
seems to tell us. This is essential in changing our path in the now, to 
reconnect to the person we were then to accept or deny, or be indifferent 
to the information we ran across. Much like the cake that we tried, we had 
to make the choice to whether we were pleased by that cake. In the same way 
a kid has to accept the ideas he is taught. Now you might have them in 
church, and it would seem to sway that person because it seems like it is 
the only choice they have, but still yet, the kid has to agree or not.
In the extreme case of abuse, that too is the case, in that a parent 
telling you over and over you will never amount to anything, might actually 
place subconscious drive in you to prove them wrong. Or a kid might accept 
it and completely waste their lives. Parents try to toughen us up in this 
way, not realizing that the power to choose is still there, and that there 
are other ways.
Perhaps that parent was taught in much the same way, and thrives off of the 
negativity and made it into something positive, and that is why they choose 
to teach in that path, but still yet they had to accept it.
This is the idea of the unconscious in that we may not be physically 
thinking it, but it is agreements based on desire over a series of time 
that seem to rule our current situations though we are not wanting the 
situations to go the way that they are going.
To regain consciousness of those kinds of decisions is to seize our power 
that was largely dormant from the delusion of self.
Like they say "You can't handle the truth" in allot of ways we can't or it 
would be apparent. Some people do whatever they can to avoid making 
decisions, they sublimate their very consciousness that they are making 
decisions.
comments.author: Christopher Harper

comments.text:
Although what you said is entirely true, you've taken that quote out of 
context (unless perhaps you're familiar with Sarte, which I am not). 
 You're overlooking what Sarte is really getting at.   Which is that we all 
make choices, and we don't always like this responsibility.

comments.author: Afrika Smith

comments.text:
It has been said in the comments that laws inhibit freedoms.  However laws 
only add consequence to action, they do not actually restrict the available 
choice.  The only way to really restrict choice is by physical restraints: 
like tying someone to a tree, or murder which is the greatest form 
restricting freedom as the murdered person will never make a choice again. 
 Possible consequences are different from actual restrictions but there are 
natural physical restrictions to our choices as well.  I can not, for 
example, fly, or go without breathing.  These physical restraints limit our 
freedoms to some extent, so a person could never be 100% free.  That being 
said people do tend to strive to give up their freedom, constantly trying 
to push responsibility for ones actions onto someone or something else as 
justification.  Or just following the flow of life and not making choices 
to do more or do different the the situation before you suggests you should 
do.﻿
